Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2015 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Huseyin Acan is "Counting Connected Combinatorial Objects." The host institution for the fellowship is Rutgers University, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Jeff Kahn.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the main goals during this fellowship was asymptotically counting various graphs with given properties, which is a subject that has attracted much attention in combinatorics for several decades.

Two important families of graphs are uniform hypergraphs, which are generalizations of usual graphs, and permutation graphs, which are obtained from permutations. In one project, the PI, with Nick Wormald and Cristiane Sato, studied connected uniform hypergraphs with a given number of edges. In a second project, the PI studied connected permutation graphs with given number of vertices and edges. As expected, and commonly observed for different types of graphs, almost all the dense uniform hypergraphs and permutation graphs are connected. This observation is enough to get asymptotic formulas for the number of dense connected graphs in question, so the interest is really in counting sparsely connected graphs.

In the case of uniform hypergraphs, the PI and coauthors followed an approach developed by Boris Pittel and Nick Wormald for counting connected graphs (2-uniform hypergraphs). In this ``inside-out'' counting approach, one first studies the connected 2-cores with a given number of vertices and edges, where a 2-core is a hypergraph with minimum degree 2. A connected hypergraph then can be obtained by attaching a rooted forest to a connected 2-core, where the roots of the trees lie in the 2-core. The added benefit of this approach is that it gives the connected 2-cores with given parameters, which is interesting in its own right. For connected permutation graphs, the the PI was able to find aymptotic formulas in some regimes for the number of edges. Connected permutation graphs correspond to indecomposable (or irreducible) permutations, which are well studied in combinatorics and algebra and which appear in other areas such as number theory and ergodic theory.

Another main goal for the fellowship was studying various random graph models and stochastic processes on these graphs. In fact, counting connected graphs with a given number of edges is important for at least two thresholds in the evolution of random graphs: the connectedness threshold and the threshold for the appearance of a giant (i.e. linear-size) component. Hence this is also related to the previous goal.

In a third study during the fellowship, the PI and Boris Pittel investigated the largest component of the intersection graph of a random chord diagram. There is no connectedness threshold for random chord diagrams due to the fact that a few isolated chords may be present even when the intersection graph is quite dense. On the other hand, this study showed that a giant component occurs when the ratio m/nlog(n) tends to a positive limit, where n and m denote the number of chords and crossings, respectively. This study complements a previous one by the same authors about the connectedness threshold and component sizes in random permutations. (A permutation can be viewed as a special chord diagram.) Besides their combinatorial nature, chord diagrams have significance in many other areas such as knot theory, analysis of data structures, statistical physics, and mathematical biology, and the results of this study could shed light on some problems in these fields.

With the same coauthor, the PI also studied bootstrap percolation on a uniform attachment graph, which is a relatively new random graph model. Bootstrap percolation, which is well studied for many families of graphs, models an infection process on a graph where the infection starts with an initial set of vertices and spreads with the rule that if at some point a vertex has sufficiently many infected neighbors, it becomes infected and stays infected forever. The final set of infected vertices depends on the initial infection as well as the underlying graph. A natural question, which was addressed in the study is: how many infected random vertices spread the infection to the entire graph?

In two other projects, the PI and his coauthors worked on two well-known conjectures. The first of these conjectures is due to Alon and Spencer from 1992, which roughly says that a positive fraction of edges in a random graph can be covered by edge-disjoint, almost-maximum cliques. The second one is due to Leighton and Moitra from 2008 about the entropy of a random permutation, where the probability distribution depends on a given tournament. In the first project, Jeff Kahn and the PI disproved the Alon-Spencer conjecture, and in the second project the PI with coauthors Pat Devlin and Jeff Kahn proved the Leighton-Moitra conjecture and strengthened a result for a special case.

During the fellowship, the PI worked with many collaborators, including four graduate students, and presented his findings in conferences and seminars, including two international conferences. Additionally, he taught three courses at his host institution, Rutgers University, and taught math for talented middle and high school students in two summer camps organized by a nonprofit institution, Absolute Academy.
